In the precision and crispness of their style they differ greatly from the florid expansiveness of the Paneqyrz‘c, the divergence indeed being so great as to point to a conscious and deliberate adaptation of manner to conventional standards of oratory on the one hand, and of epistolography on the other. In the tenth book, however, we find real letters⁷ for in these Pliny writes to Trajan for advice on various problems of provincial administration, and the emperor replies in notes, the eminently practical spirit of which forms one of the most noticeable features of the correspondence.

From his works we are able to form a fairly adequate idea of our author’s character: a man of little more than mediocre ability‚ upon whose imagination his own activities invariably loomed large3 pedantic in matters of literature, irresolute and vacillating in matters of administration, vain to the extreme of vanity, of impenetrable complacent-y, yet withal amiable, kindly‚ conscientious, standing for what was good, and genuinely intel-ested in literature.
